target_title: atspi-device-x11: Support adding grabs given a keysym

note.body: Oh, good point. I think it's probably better to create a new function, to be safe. We can deprecate the existing one.

target_title: segfault when invoking Evolution as another user (after `su - another-user`)

note.body:
> WebKit could then query the uid and ignore the address from the display if the user doesn't match.

Sure, that would avoid the WebKit crash, but the user's accessibility bus is still broken for all applications, not just WebKit.

> That raises the question of what to do if the WebKit process is running as root, assuming that that is even possible.

If run as root, it's just going to crash when trying to execute bubblewrap, so let's not worry about this.

> If you aren't going to try to support a11y on GUI apps running as root, then removing Display::accessibilityBusAddressX11() from WebKit should be safe and might stop this crash.

OK, I'll point the accessibility maintainers to this.

target_title: atspi-device-x11: Support adding grabs given a keysym

note.body: Thanks for confirming my interpretation of the map_modifier call. However, I have a slightly different issue with it for now: Because you definitely should not know which device backend you're using, and the new a11y manager backend only supports XKB keysyms, the map_modifier call would receive a XKB keysym in this case. However, currently, the X11 backend expects hardware key codes. What would you do - introduce a map_modifier_keysym, or do a backward-incompatible change and expect keysyms everywhere? Both approaches would allow the clients (e. g. Orca) to use the new behavior based on the AT-SPI2 version, so this is more to your preference.

target_title: atspi-device-x11: Support adding grabs given a keysym

note.body:
On X11, atspi_device_map_modifier allows keys to be used as modifiers
even if they aren't defined as modifiers in the keymap (insert, for
instance). The X11 back end activates key grabs that use these "virtual"
modifiers when the modifier key is pressed and then deactivates them when the
key is released. Looking at Matt's interface, he has handled this differently.

I think one option would be to document that atspi_device_map_modifier may
grab the modifier and ensure that Orca only calls it when the modifier should be grabbed (if the modifier is no longer meant to be grabbed, then ensure
that unmap_modifier is called). I don't know of anything using this API aside from Orca. This should do what you need while not
breaking the X11 code. Of course, I'm open to other suggestions in terms of
how best to do this.

target_title: segfault when invoking Evolution as another user (after `su - another-user`)

note.body: I'm wondering if this is happening on X11. Since at-spi-bus-launcher writes the bus address to the X display, it might be a good idea to also write the uid owning the process. WebKit could then query the uid and ignore the address from the display if the user doesn't match. That raises the question of what to do if the WebKit process is running as root, assuming that that is even possible. Iirc the X atom is there to allow GUI applications running as the superuser to connect to an accessibility bus run by a normal user. It is another thing that, in theory, applications shouldn't be doing, and it might be primarily a historical thing at this point. That code also only works on X11 and not Wayland. If you aren't going to try to support a11y on GUI apps running as root, then removing Display::accessibilityBusAddressX11() from WebKit should be safe and might stop this crash.

target_title: segfault when invoking Evolution as another user (after `su - another-user`)

note.body:
> You **cannot** just run **any** GUI application using `su - whatever` like you'd do with a shell script or a CLI tool; accessibility is going to be the least of your problems: in GNOME alone you'll break things like GVFS, input methods, or any other part of the system that uses any form of IPC mechanism that is tied to a (machine, user) tuple, like D-Bus.

Yes.

> The only reasonable way to handle that is to immediately abort.

Right, that's what I would do. But how to detect this condition?

target_title: segfault when invoking Evolution as another user (after `su - another-user`)

note.body:
> On the other hand, clearly users do this anyway :)

People on Linux do all sorts of broken stuff, doesn't mean they are right: it just means that they read on some website somewhere some advice that somebody wrote 15 years ago, and nobody knows any better.

You **cannot** just run **any** GUI application using `su - whatever` like you'd do with a shell script or a CLI tool; accessibility is going to be the least of your problems: in GNOME alone you'll break things like GVFS, input methods, or any other part of the system that uses any form of IPC mechanism that is tied to a (machine, user) tuple, like D-Bus.

People need to understand how systems work, before attempting to run random commands on the command line.

>  and it would be nice for the accessibility service to not break when it happens.

The only reasonable way to handle that is to immediately abort.

target_title: segfault when invoking Evolution as another user (after `su - another-user`)

note.body:
So the problem is that org.a11y.Bus.GetAddress returns an address that the user doesn't have permission to open. On the one hand, it's definitely user error since a reasonable user should not run applications with the permissions of one user account within the graphical session of another user account; that almost always leads to broken stuff. On the other hand, clearly users do this anyway :) and it would be nice for the accessibility service to not break when it happens.

I'm not actually sure how to fix it, though. at-spi2-core is just doing what it's told and I'm not sure how exactly we would check whether the user account it's being run as is the "correct" user account for the session bus it's using or not.

target_title: at-spi-bus-launcher: Fix GIOChannel leak in init_sigterm_handling
Decide upon a signature for event signals

note.body:
> I'm filing a separate bug about this since this task may get a little involved:
>
> * Synching the C code in at-spi2-core to its XML interfaces is easy enough, but...
> * We should look at what toolkits actually do. Do they need fixes? Do they have equivalent signatures? Which ones do we want to keep?

IIUC, syncing C code in this repo and XML spec is done now, by these commits:

* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/at-spi2-core/-/commit/12a7706eebee7aa79ac1cf383a51f09d0d4a5ff8
* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/at-spi2-core/-/commit/ab979c443ac11375a6baecfca897b0a44acdf861
* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/at-spi2-core/-/commit/f0781465a75595f74b8cbcd582b7b35b46ee6349

GTK 4 also adheres to these signatures. Corresponding fix for `object:children-changed` that was previously using a different signature:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/-/commit/0749f968f455d1d220a48cdeaef5071aae9e943b

Qt 6 now also adheres to the documented signatures, corresponding commit:

https://code.qt.io/cgit/qt/qtbase.git/commit/?id=fdf87fdce1c8b926b1c1ee9254aa4b0fc1840d82

So at least the XML spec, GTK 3, GTK 4 and Qt 6 should all be in sync now. Did you have any other specific toolkits in mind?

> * Need tests for each signature type we want to support.

That's probably still open.
